description: Probably from Middle Low German glum (“glum”), related to German dialectal glumm (“gloomy, troubled, turbid”). More at gloomy.

examples: I […] frighten people by my glum face.

description: From Middle English glomen, glommen, glomben, gloumben (“to frown, look sullen”), from *glom (“gloom”). More at gloom.

examples: That they be deaf and dumb, And play silence and glum

verbs.description: glum (third-person singular simple present glums, present participle glumming, simple past and past participle glummed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To look sullen; to be of a sour countenance; to be glum.
examples: upon me he gan to loure and glum, Enforcing him so for to ryse withall, But that I shortly unto hem did cum, With his thre hedes he spytte all his venum
